# The In-House Take On Billable Hours
## Notes to my (legal) self.
By [Olga V. Mack](https://abovethelaw.com/author/olgamack/)  
onJune 4, 2021 at 5:48 PMJune 4, 2021 at 3:16 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/the-in-house-take-on-billable-hours/&text=The%20In-House%20Take%20On%20Billable%20Hours)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/the-in-house-take-on-billable-hours/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/the-in-house-take-on-billable-hours/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Olga V. Mack is the CEO of [Parley Pro](https://parleypro.com/), a next-generation contract management company that has pioneered online negotiation technology. Olga embraces legal innovation and had dedicated her career to improving and shaping the future of law. She is convinced that the legal profession will emerge even stronger, more resilient, and more inclusive than before by embracing technology. Olga is also an award-winning general counsel, operations professional, startup advisor, public speaker, adjunct professor, and entrepreneur. She founded the [Women Serve on Boards](https://www.womenserveonboards.com/) movement that advocates for women to participate on corporate boards of Fortune 500 companies. She authored [Get on Board: Earning Your Ticket to a Corporate Board Seat](https://www.amazon.com/Get-Board-Earning-Ticket-Corporate/dp/1949991407) and [Fundamentals of Smart Contract Security](https://www.amazon.com/Fundamentals-Smart-Contract-Security-Richard-ebook/dp/B07S8YF27G). You can follow Olga on Twitter @olgavmack.

# Which Law Firms Are The Best Places To Work In NYC? (2016)
## Which law firms are considered the cream of the crop in the city that never sleeps?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 11, 2016 at 2:45 PMOctober 11, 2016 at 2:14 PM
45
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/which-law-firms-are-the-best-places-to-work-in-nyc-2016/&text=Which%20Law%20Firms%20Are%20The%20Best%20Places%20To%20Work%20In%20NYC?%20(2016))[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/which-law-firms-are-the-best-places-to-work-in-nyc-2016/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/which-law-firms-are-the-best-places-to-work-in-nyc-2016/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Since 2008, Crain’s New York Business has produced a list of the Best Places to Work in New York City. Each year, a few law firms sneak onto the list, much like the situation with Fortune’s 100 Best Companies to Work For list.

This year, seven law firms made Crain’s list, while only [six made Fortune’s list](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/03/which-biglaw-firms-are-the-best-places-to-work/), as of March 2016. Just two firms overlap between Crain’s and Fortune’s lists.

Which ones are considered the cream of the crop in the city that never sleeps?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Before we get to the top law firms to work for, let’s check out [Crain’s methodology](http://www.bestplacestoworknyc.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=26&Itemid=43):

[Crain’s New York Business partnered with] Best Companies Group [to] conduct[] a simple yet thorough company assessment. The assessment is a two-part process designed to gather detailed data about each participating company. In part one, the employer completes a questionnaire and in part two, employees of the company complete an employee survey [with questions focused on everything from benefits to opportunities for advancement].

The collected information from the two instruments will be combined to produce a detailed set of data enabling the analysts to determine the strengths and opportunities of the participating companies. The workplaces are ranked based on this data.

We should also mention that there is a $199 fee to participate Best Places to Work in New York City ranking, with an additional fee on top of that if your company needs paper-based surveys. If you don’t pay, you don’t get to play, and you won’t be able to receive the bragging rights attendant with being a “best place to work for.”

These are the seven law firms on [Crain’s 2016 Best Places to Work in NYC](http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20160928/SMALLBIZ/160929892/crains-unveils-the-100-best-places-to-work-in-new-york-city-in-2016) list:

Alston & Bird and Cooley are the only firms to appear on both Crain’s list and Fortune’s list. Congratulations to both firms for this high achievement. Getting people to fill out questionnaires (that you had to pay for, in advance) can be excrutiatingly painful!

Vivia Chen of [The Careerist](http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2016/10/10/7-firms-not-on-wall-street-make-best-place-to-work-list/) had some color commentary on the Crain’s list:

[I]sn’t it curious how indigenous big New York firms seldom (actually, never) make those lists of “best” or “nicest” or “happiest” places to work? …

The only true New York firms are Adam Leitman Bailey, a real estate boutique, and Frankfurt Kurnit, an entertainment specialty shop.

So here’s the subtext: Big, powerful New York firms don’t need those “pleasant to work” awards. That’s for small fries and out-of-towners.

Have these rankings actually been earned? Can you think of a law firm that deserves to be recognized, but hasn’t been? [Email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=Crain's%20Best%20Places%20to%20Work) or text us (646-820-8477) and let us know.

# Abusive Partners Are Still A Problem Firms Have A Hard Time Facing
## Firms are still behind on this.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onAugust 8, 2019 at 4:16 PMAugust 8, 2019 at 2:59 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/08/abusive-partners-are-still-a-problem-firms-have-a-hard-time-facing/&text=Abusive%20Partners%20Are%20Still%20A%20Problem%20Firms%20Have%20A%20Hard%20Time%20Facing)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/08/abusive-partners-are-still-a-problem-firms-have-a-hard-time-facing/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/08/abusive-partners-are-still-a-problem-firms-have-a-hard-time-facing/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The “screamer” was a creature that existed in law firm lore to terrorize new associates and staff. There was always some partner — or partners — within the firm structure whose book of business shielded them from common workplace courtesy. Screamers didn’t have to actually scream at anyone. Sure, there were tales of partners hurling objects out the window — or at other attorneys — but more often than not the abuse manifests in the sort of passive-aggressive dress downs that systematically undermine a person’s basic sense of self-worth.

While mental health initiatives are [getting some press these days](https://www.law.com/2019/06/17/law-firms-tackle-mental-health-one-initiative-at-a-time/), but these programs almost always focus on providing wellness services to those facing stress, without directly confronting those in management positions about treating employees better, and by extension, keeping stress down.

A series of tips received here at Above the Law — hodgepodged together into one cohesive narrative below — tell a story that, if true, would be a stark reminder that in Biglaw circles, management maintains a stigma when it comes to mental health and a significant blindspot when it comes to the possibility that a partner might be contributing to a hostile environment:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
An associate left the office in an ambulance. An abusive partner had pushed the associate hard for years and it apparently became too much on the latest matter. The group is dismissing it and trying to sweep it under the rug as the associate’s shortcomings because it was mental health related.

We’ve only heard from people sympathetic to the associate in this instance so we’re not going to speculate on the truth of the matter, but the fact that associates feel that the firm would not only downplay an abusive relationship, but would see mental health as an excuse to shift blame entirely upon the victim, speaks to the fractured sense of trust in the work environment. If mental health enters the vocabulary of the legal profession, it can’t come in only as a means to whitewash bad management.

In another story, [a legal secretary has filed suit over a pair of Venable partners](http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/legal-secretarys-suit-claims-partners-tirades-constituted-sex-bias-caused-panic-attack) who “yelled, humiliated and demeaned her to such an extent that their conduct constituted sex discrimination under California’s fair employment law.”

“The days when an attorney can make enough money to excuse the verbal abuse and humiliation of the women that work for him are over,” the suit says. “Legal staff is not required to tolerate and even babysit lawyers through tantrums supposedly caused by ‘stress’ or ‘pressure.’ Verbal abuse and humiliation alter the terms and conditions of employment. When this conduct is directed at women, it is sex discrimination.”

From Pilot and Above The Law  
While there are certainly scenarios where this sort of abuse comes from a place of gender dynamics and only targets women, this abuse is not always a matter of sex discrimination and it’s unfortunate that this rubric is one of the only effective means of addressing it. Too many instances can slip through the cracks when sex isn’t the clear impetus behind the abuse.

But more important than finding the right legal redress, firm leadership across the industry needs to get its act together and start holding peers accountable. There’s no amount of rainmaking that justifies keeping a hurricane in a corner office. We often point out that a law degree doesn’t necessarily provide business acumen, but it also fails to train management skills. Biglaw firms should start taking this seriously too.

[Legal secretary’s suit claims partners’ tirades constituted sex bias, caused panic attack](http://www.abajournal.com/news/article/legal-secretarys-suit-claims-partners-tirades-constituted-sex-bias-caused-panic-attack) [ABA Journal]

# Can Women Lawyers Ever Find Equality In Biglaw?
## As long as the profits keep rolling in, why should Biglaw care about gender equality?
By [Richard B. Cohen](https://abovethelaw.com/author/richardcohen/)  
onApril 13, 2017 at 7:44 PMApril 13, 2017 at 3:24 PM
43
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/can-women-lawyers-ever-find-equality-in-biglaw/&text=Can%20Women%20Lawyers%20Ever%20Find%20Equality%20In%20Biglaw?)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/can-women-lawyers-ever-find-equality-in-biglaw/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/can-women-lawyers-ever-find-equality-in-biglaw/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Hey — who cares if Biglaw is white and male as long as it can charge [$2,000 per hour](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/2000-an-hour-lawyers-thats-one-way-to-fund-salary-increases/) (or more). It’s all about the money, after all. Isn’t it?

Of course.

As long as the profits keep rolling in, why should Biglaw care about gender equality? Yeah, I know – clients are starting to demand it; let’s see what happens. (The CEO of United Airlines probably had a similar lack of concern the other day about the [passenger dragged off one of his planes](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/united-passenger-lawyers-up-will-likely-re-accommodate-airline-in-court/), until the PR nightmare hit).

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Escape From Alcatraz

I went “over the wall” and escaped from Biglaw; I know it as a grinding law factory that demands loyalty but is anything but loyal in return. “Collegiality” is probably the most overused, disingenuous word in the Biglaw recruiting lexicon, and I suspect that every Biglaw firm touts it as its number one quality – and many naïve (new) lawyers believe the pitch.

Yet likely no one who has ever plied the lawyer’s trade in Biglaw can say – if they are honest – that their firm is truly “collegial.” Fat fees and greed are the prevailing ethos – how can you afford to be “collegial” when “shareholder value” is the summum bonum?

The same is true about those more recent recruiting come-ons such as “family friendly” and “diversity and inclusion.” Such noble – but empty – words! Try counting the number of female partners or partners of color at Biglaw – see how diverse it really is. And how many lawyers with kids – male or female, but mostly female – who were smilingly promised “family friendly” hours were subtly hip-checked out the door for not billing enough after a respectable period of time had passed. I know a few.

In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Nothing must get in the way of billing, the billable hour, the almost-sacred realization rate, or profits per partner.

Certainly not you, lady!

Gender Pay Disparity

A 2016 “[fact sheet](http://www.nationalpartnership.org/research-library/workplace-fairness/fair-pay/4-2016-ny-wage-gap.pdf)” published by the National Partnership For Women & Families stated that in New York, women are paid 87 cents for every dollar paid a man. And recall the equal pay complaint of the [U.S. Women’s Soccer](http://employmentdiscrimination.fisherbroyles.com/2016/04/should-hope-solo-be-paid-less-than-clint-dempsey-isnt-this-employment-discrimination/) team?

So we know that women generally get paid less than men. What about in the law?

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
A Major, Lindsey & Africa survey released in late 2016 found that women law partners average about 69% of the compensation of male partners. Above the Law also [reported](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/nyc-bar-report-reveals-minorities-have-a-60-higher-attrition-rate-asian-attorneys-leaving-at-an-alarming-rate/) at the time on the NYC Bar Association’s [2015 Diversity Benchmarking Report](http://documents.nycbar.org/files/NYC_Bar_2015_Diversity_Benchmarking_Report.pdf), which stated that “[d]espite more than a decade of New York law firms pledging to enhance diversity in their ranks, minority representation within associate and partners levels stalled last year, and attrition rates for female and minority attorneys remained disproportionately high.”

As the Law Journal noted, “Overall, firms are struggling to meet key statements in the diversity principles they signed onto, and women and minority attorneys are leaving at high numbers. Among all attorneys, 18.4 percent of women and 20.8 percent of minorities left last year, compared with only 12.9 percent of white men.”

Women take note – “While only 44 percent of current associates are white men, they make up 75 percent of current partners. … about 44 percent of associates are women, compared to 20 percent of partners.”

So it’s no surprise that women have [recently sued ](http://employmentdiscrimination.fisherbroyles.com/2016/09/what-do-at-least-5-biglaw-firms-and-the-u-s-womens-soccer-team-have-in-common/)at least five Biglaw firms for alleged pay disparity under the [Equal Pay Act](http://www.eeoc.gov/laws/statutes/epa.cfm) (“EPA”).

Mansplaining and Manterrupting

And then there’s the harassment, and the “bro culture,” and the “mansplaining.”

Speaking of “[manterrupting](http://employmentdiscrimination.fisherbroyles.com/2016/09/handling-manterruption-and-bro-priating-in-the-oval-office/),” the New York Times defined it as “unnecessary interruption of a woman by a man.” Every woman I know has had this happen to her.

And apropos of that, did you catch the article in the [Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/posteverything/wp/2017/04/11/if-gorsuch-is-like-his-colleagues-hell-constantly-interrupt-the-female-justices/?utm_term=.f5dfaad3929d) this week reporting on a [law review study](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/it-doesnt-get-better-women-supreme-court-justices-get-interrupted-too/) finding that “Supreme Court justices are some of the most powerful individuals in the country, yet the female justices [find themselves interrupted](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/05/gender-dynamics-at-scotus-female-justices-interrupted-more-often-than-male-justices/) not only by their male colleagues, but also by their subordinates: the male advocates who are attempting to persuade them.… The situation only seems to be getting worse with more women on the court.”

So – do you think that gender pay disparity, harassment, and marginalization are mere incidentals, as opposed to an insidious inequality practiced society-wide – and ingrained in Biglaw as part of its longstanding model?

The “Iron Law” of Biglaw

Maybe it all adds up to the fact that the Biglaw model is, by its very history and nature, inherently unequal – unequal to all but the ruling few, who happen to be male and white. And for women – who were, after all, only allowed relatively recently into law schools, the ABA and Biglaw, it is even more unequal – and will continue to be.

First, consider the entrance requirements. The Ivy League law schools, being the Biglaw gatekeepers, select those who will “make it” in Biglaw, and train/brand/clone them to fit right in.

And they charge an indecent entrance fee to cull out the herd – enough to keep new lawyers indentured to Biglaw for many years – and long enough for Biglaw to make quite a profit until it sends (most of) them packing. It’s sort of like the relationship between college and professional sports, or the baseball minor leagues to MLB, or graduate instructors in college.

For its part, Biglaw must pay ever-higher salaries so that the associates can and will be enticed (or forced) to stay – and for which the associates are required to work on an assembly line that gets faster and faster each year (I once said “think Lucy Ricardo on the chocolate candy assembly line”). And for which client fees must be jacked up ever higher.

Takeaway

So – who gets the payoff? The big payday?

As always – follow the money. And the trail leads to a firmly entrenched cadre of power brokers.

And guess what gender and color they are?

# Allen & Overy And O'Melveny Are Considering Merger (Please Name It Allen & O'Melvery)
## Gigantic news in the legal industry as two major firms discuss transatlantic merger.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onApril 6, 2018 at 1:38 PMApril 6, 2018 at 3:41 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/allen-overy-and-omelveny-are-considering-merger-please-name-it-allen-omelvery/&text=Allen%20&%20Overy%20And%20O’Melveny%20Are%20Considering%20Merger%20(Please%20Name%20It%20Allen%20&%20O’Melvery))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/allen-overy-and-omelveny-are-considering-merger-please-name-it-allen-omelvery/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/allen-overy-and-omelveny-are-considering-merger-please-name-it-allen-omelvery/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
UPDATE: Now O’Melveny says they aren’t merging. [See update here](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/omelveny-tells-atl-we-have-no-plans-to-merge-and-never-have/).

Two firms that haven’t been shy about their interest in expansion are reportedly in “deep” discussions over a potential international merger. Magic Circle stalwart Allen & Overy and America’s O’Melveny & Myers are considering joining forces to create a new megafirm.

Christine Simmons and Rose Walker of the American Lawyer reported the nascent merger about an hour ago:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Allen & Overy and O’Melveny & Myers are in deep discussions about a potential combination, according to two sources briefed on the matter.

If a merger deal is finalized between both firms, it would create a 3,000-lawyer business with roughly $2.8 billion in combined gross revenue. Details of the talks, to date, have been contained to only a small number of senior figures, although Allen & Overy partners were told in January that the Magic Circle firm was in talks with several U.S. firms about a potential combination.

Would this influx of Americans cure [Allen & Overy’s atrocious gender pay disparity](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/another-biglaw-firm-reports-dismal-gender-pay-gap/)? I’m guessing no.

The tie-up would tread the well-worn path of previous cross-Atlantic deals like Clifford Chance’s takeover of Rogers & Wells, Norton Rose’s [takeover of Fulbright & Jaworski](https://abovethelaw.com/2012/11/law-firm-merger-mania-fulbright-jaworski-smells-sweet-to-norton-rose/) and [absorption of Chadborne](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/biglaw-merger-means-the-end-of-chadbourne-parke/), and [Bryan Cave’s merger with Berwin Leighton Paisner](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/02/another-day-another-transatlantic-biglaw-merger-to-create-a-1600-lawyer-megafirm/). It appears that in the sport of Biglaw, everyone wants to play in both courts (see, that’s a double entendre!).

But every merger is special in its own way, so we’ll have to wait and see how this one plays out. Swiss Verein? Acquisition? True Merger? It’s all a mystery to us at this point.

# Looking To Get Fired At This Biglaw Firm? Good Luck With That!
## This firm apparently wants to retain its associates, no matter what.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 5, 2022 at 3:45 PMAugust 5, 2022 at 2:23 PM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/looking-to-get-fired-at-this-biglaw-firm-good-luck-with-that/&text=Looking%20To%20Get%20Fired%20At%20This%20Biglaw%20Firm?%20Good%20Luck%20With%20That!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/looking-to-get-fired-at-this-biglaw-firm-good-luck-with-that/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/looking-to-get-fired-at-this-biglaw-firm-good-luck-with-that/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
How hard it is to get fired.

— a midlevel associate at Alston & Bird, in response to a question found in the [American Lawyer Midlevel Associates Survey](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2022/08/03/the-2022-midlevel-associates-survey-quotable-associates/) about what most surprised them about working at their current firm. More notable and quotable responses can be found [here](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2022/08/03/the-2022-midlevel-associates-survey-quotable-associates/).

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# How To Work Fewer Holiday Weekends In Biglaw
## Yes, it is possible to be a Biglaw associate (or staff attorney, or counsel, or partner) and not work every holiday weekend.
By [D.W. Randolph](https://abovethelaw.com/author/dwrandolph/)  
onJune 6, 2023 at 2:14 PMJune 6, 2023 at 1:31 PM
13
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/how-to-work-fewer-holiday-weekends-in-biglaw/&text=How%20To%20Work%20Fewer%20Holiday%20Weekends%20In%20Biglaw)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/how-to-work-fewer-holiday-weekends-in-biglaw/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/how-to-work-fewer-holiday-weekends-in-biglaw/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
How did you spend your Memorial Day Weekend?  I’m willing to bet that, while many of your friends and family were traveling, BBQ-ing, and relaxing on the beach, you were stuck inside working on an assignment that you were told (or made to feel) *had to* be done over the holiday weekend, to meet client demands and/or partner expectations.  If this was you, and you’d like to work less (or not at all) on future holiday weekends, read on…

Yes, it is possible to be a Biglaw associate (or staff attorney, or counsel, or partner) and not work every holiday weekend (i.e., Friday through holiday Monday).  How, you ask?  The magic formula is:

strategizing + planning + optimizing optics =

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
greater likelihood of being off or working less on a holiday weekend

First, it’s important to emphasize that there are no guarantees in Biglaw.  Even using the “magic” formula, you may, and likely will, have to work some holiday weekends.  But you may be able to take some holiday weekends entirely off, and work fewer other holiday weekends than you have been historically, if you employ the magic formula.

Let’s take a closer look at the magic formula:

- Strategizing. Timing is everything.  Determine your end goal, work backwards, and strategize to make it happen.  Your goal is to not have to work over the holiday weekend.  Given the nature of Biglaw practice, you know that generally, if a draft document or other work product is with someone else, you won’t be able to or need to work on it at the same time.  Accordingly, your strategy ought to be to send the work product to the other person to review/deal with it shortly before the holiday weekend (but not too far in advance, such that they might dump it back in your lap right before or during the weekend).  Ideally, you’d send it sometime between Wednesday night through around noon on Friday before the holiday weekend.  That timing likely ensures that the recipient won’t have enough time to review it, comment, and send it back to you or request a phone call to discuss it between when you send it and when the holiday weekend ends.

### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)

From Pilot and Above The Law  
plus

- Planning. You can’t always plan your workload in Biglaw, but when you can, it usually pays to do so.  If you know you’re going to want to distribute work product sometime between Wednesday and midday Friday before a holiday weekend, then you’ll need to work backwards and plan accordingly to get the distribution ready before then.  Have you determined whose comments or sign-off you’ll need to distribute (if anyone), and allotted sufficient time for them to review and sign off?  Have you allocated at least a few hours (of your own time or staff members’ time) to proofread and format the document prior to distribution?  And keep in mind that deadlines are hard and fast for some, but not others, in Biglaw.  When you can build in some extra time “cushion” for yourself, it’s a good idea to do so.
plus

- Optimizing optics. Keep in mind the importance of “optics” in Biglaw (i.e., how something will look to others, such as your supervising attorney, client, or opposing counsel).  If you’re successfully going to pull off a work-free or reduced-work holiday weekend, and not have it come back to bite you later, you’ll need to optimize optics.  It’s a balancing act—the earlier you send a distribution during the window of Wednesday to midday Friday before a holiday weekend, the more likely it is it will get thrown back to you, and the later you send during that window, the more likely it is the recipient will recognize what you’re doing, label you disorganized, opportunistic, or a jerk, and try to “return the favor” on a subsequent occasion.
This magic formula works best when either: (i) you’re only working on one matter at a time (e.g., fully committed to one massive litigation matter) or (ii) you can get all of your matters/assignments to line up (e.g., all your transactions are moving at approximately the same pace and are at approximately the same stage).  That’s admittedly not always possible.

### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)

From Pilot and Above The Law  
If you can’t secure an entirely work-free weekend, one other way to maximize your free time and minimize your work time during the weekend is to understand human nature, and align your working hours with others’ likely working hours.  In my experience, most people who are going to work some, but not all, of a holiday weekend, do so on Saturday morning and Monday afternoon.  If you know that the partner or client that you’re working with has this tendency, then plan to set aside a few hours around the same times, to do work and deal with requests that they send to you, and plan anything you want to be totally out-of-pocket for on Saturday night, Sunday, or Monday morning.

One final tip: travel at off-peak times, when it’s least likely to be disruptive/noticeable to your colleagues and clients, and you won’t have to deal with likely travel stress and delays.  (Biglaw is challenging and stressful enough, as it is!)  This might mean that you fly or drive somewhere on the Wednesday or Thursday night before a holiday weekend, work remotely for a few days, and then return on the Tuesday or Wednesday night after the holiday weekend (assuming your firm will let you work remotely, which is not a given, these days).  Or, you can plan to work in the office, but not in your usual office, if your firm will allow it.  For example, let’s say that you’re normally based in New York City, but want to spend the holiday weekend in the LA area, and your firm has offices in both cities.  You might work in the NYC office from Monday through Wednesday the week before the holiday, fly to LA overnight Wednesday-Thursday, work in the LA office Thursday and Friday, enjoy the holiday weekend through Monday in LA, work in the LA office Tuesday, and then fly home Tuesday-Wednesday overnight.  That way, you’re still satisfying your firm’s requirements to work in the (an) office a certain number of days a week, and are available to meet team and client demands during typical working hours, but you’re already in LA to enjoy your free time there over the weekend, in advance of the actual weekend itself.  Working in other offices is also a great way to connect with colleagues that you usually work with from afar, and to build your professional network.

D.W. Randolph is a pseudonym for an attorney who is or was a partner, “rainmaker,” and practice leader at an Am Law 100 firm, who has practiced law at multiple Am Law / Vault top law firms in New York City and another large U.S. city, over the span of many years, and the author of the acclaimed “tell-all” book and resource guide to all things Biglaw, entitled [Big Law Confidential](https://amzn.to/3Ky6OkT) (affiliate link). D.W. has served in firmwide and office-level leadership positions within their Biglaw firms and led or been involved in nearly all aspects of Biglaw firm operations, from summer associate and attorney hiring, compensation, performance evaluation and promotion, to firm governance and initiatives focused on diversity and inclusion, and more.  D.W. graduated with honors from a law school that has historically been ranked by U.S. News & World Report as one of the top 10 law schools in the U.S. and has taught at a law school that has historically been ranked by U.S. News & World Report as one of the top 14 law schools in the U.S.

# Despite Wildfire Tragedy, International Law Firm Decides To Hold Hawaiian-Themed Party
## The firm is donating to the Wildfire Relief Fund -- it's the very least they can do.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onAugust 21, 2023 at 4:16 PMAugust 21, 2023 at 3:08 PM
13
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/addleshaw-goddard-hawaii-party/&text=Despite%20Wildfire%20Tragedy,%20International%20Law%20Firm%20Decides%20To%20Hold%20Hawaiian-Themed%20Party)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/addleshaw-goddard-hawaii-party/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/addleshaw-goddard-hawaii-party/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo by PATRICK T. FALLON/AFP via Getty Images)

The scope of the Hawaiian wildfire tragedy[ continues to grow](https://www.huffpost.com/entry/maui-wildfires-missing-death-toll-biden-visit_n_64e360e6e4b09133924c43aa), with 114 confirmed dead and 850 still missing. Given the loss and devastation, it’s never been more vital to see Maui and the entirety of Hawai’i as more than just a tropical locale for tourists to frolic. Real people, not just some caricature of a vacation hot spot, are the ones suffering right now.

Against this backdrop, Addleshaw Goddard, a global law firm with 1,400 lawyers that’s headquartered in London, is holding a Hawai’i-themed party. In a baffling revelation, the [firm told Roll on Friday](https://www.rollonfriday.com/news-content/exclusive-addleshaw-goddard-defends-hawaii-themed-party) they thought about seeming insensitive for using Hawaiian identity for their fun times in the face of human suffering, but ultimately gave it a big shoulder shrug and plowed on with their good time:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
“In light of the terrible events in Hawaii we of course considered cancelling or trying to re-brand the event”, said the firm, “but decided after great thought and some consultation to go ahead explaining to staff earlier this week that it was not a thoughtless and insensitive decision but one to which we have given considerable thought”.

It’s just… so close to seeing the point, but ultimately it’s a swing and a miss.

The firm did note they’re holding a fundraiser to benefit relief efforts:

“Our thoughts are of course with the people of Maui”, said the firm, and now “a charity raffle will run on the evening with proceeds going to the Hawaii Wildfire Relief Fund and the Addleshaw Goddard Trust has also agreed to match fund”.

In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Obviously the donation is welcome, but you can’t just write a check and get away with bad taste. The firm denies that employees complained about the inappropriateness of the themed event, saying, “As far as we know, there have been no protestations from staff, certainly none have come to the attention of our senior leadership team.”

But the firm put “great thought” into the event and *still* decided to go with the Hawai’i theme. No one is objecting to a firm party, but out of respect for those dead, injured, and missing, put away the leis and grass skirts. That’s just unnecessary. You can — and should — still donate to the relief effort but opting for a different theme would seem the prudent way forward.

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). # Biglaw Associates Do Not Understand How Small Towns Work
## You are not being judged for your capacity to worthlessly bloviate.
By [Atticus T. Lunch](https://abovethelaw.com/author/atticustlynch/)  
onSeptember 27, 2016 at 12:39 PM
37
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/biglaw-associates-do-not-understand-how-small-towns-work/&text=Biglaw%20Associates%20Do%20Not%20Understand%20How%20Small%20Towns%20Work)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/biglaw-associates-do-not-understand-how-small-towns-work/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/biglaw-associates-do-not-understand-how-small-towns-work/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

You’re not that great, hotshot.

Ed. Note: This is an open letter crafted while watching a fifth-year associate from Biglaw World out of their element at a small town deposition.

Dear fifth-year associate they sent from Biglaw World to do this deposition:

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Yes, I am the second youngest person in this room besides you. However, that I live in a smaller city does not mean your five years of experience are more valuable than my eight. Years at Biglaw firm are not dog years. I mean, while you may feel valued like a dog — not one of those froufrou dogs that fits in purses — your four years preparing statements of material facts to be reviewed by two layers of partners do not make you a better lawyer.

Also, practicing law is not professional baseball. That is to say, I live here because this is where I want to live. I am not somehow stuck wallowing in Double A while you are up there in the show. I don’t want to work there, in no small part because it would mean working with or in close proximity to you. Also, to the extent baseball and law are analogous, I am starting every day at Third Base while you get to pinch run once a week. And if this deposition is any indication of your relative skill, you just got thrown out at third by two steps in a 10-0 game.

Oh, sweet Jesus. Now you’re making speaking objections. This is not a parliamentary debate competition! You are not being judged for your capacity to worthlessly bloviate.

Well, I mean, that’s not entirely true. We, the other five attorneys at this table, we’re judging you. And we don’t like you. We have spent significant amounts of time forging a collegial bar. We like and respect each other. To the extent we make speaking objections, they are short and serve a discreet purpose. You, on the other hand, are still talking. That means that one of us is going to have to remind you of the rules of civil procedure… well, here I go.

# Non-Sequiturs: 08.10.16
## * "NEW CIVILITY WATCH: Dem Senate candidate and former Ohio Gov. Ted Strickland: Scalia's death 'happened at a good time.'" [[Instapundit](https://pjmedia.com/instapundit/241002/)] * A Skull and Bones society for top NYC law firms? Professor Rick Swedloff discusses a secretive group whose membership includes some of Biglaw's biggest names. [[SSRN](http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2820654)] * A notable new petition (filed by Professor Orin Kerr and Marcia Hofmann) in a high-profile appeal about the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act. [[Volokh Conspiracy](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2016/08/10/petition-for-rehearing-en-banc-filed-in-the-9th-circuits-recent-cfaa-case-facebook-v-vachani/?utm_term=.0212dcff3f71)] * Donald Trump's infamous ["Second Amendment"](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/donald-trump-suggests-second-amendment-people-may-want-to-assassinate-hillary-clinton-before-she-takes-away-their-guns/) quip is protected by the First Amendment -- but just barely, according to Professor Noah Feldman. [[Bloomberg View via How Appealing](http://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/081016.html#068274)] * Jury consultant Roy Futterman of [DOAR](https://www.doar.com/) wonders: is concern about prejudicing jurors actually driving them to using the internet for decision-making? [[Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/are-we-driving-jurors-to-the-internet-perspective/)] * Could the ABA someday lose its power to accredit law schools? Steven J. Harper thinks its day of reckoning is coming closer. [[The Belly of the Beast](https://thelawyerbubble.com/2016/08/10/the-abas-terrible-horrible-no-good-very-bad-day/)]
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)

# Prestigious Biglaw Firm Enacts Global Work-From-Home Policy Over Coronavirus Concerns
## When will other firms offer work-from-home solutions so employees can remain safe?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 12, 2020 at 2:14 PMMarch 12, 2020 at 1:55 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/prestigious-biglaw-firm-enacts-global-work-from-home-policy-over-coronavirus-concerns/&text=Prestigious%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Enacts%20Global%20Work-From-Home%20Policy%20Over%20Coronavirus%20Concerns)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/prestigious-biglaw-firm-enacts-global-work-from-home-policy-over-coronavirus-concerns/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/prestigious-biglaw-firm-enacts-global-work-from-home-policy-over-coronavirus-concerns/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Earlier this week, [Quinn Emanuel shuttered its New York office](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/quinn-emanuel-new-york-coronavirus/) after one of the firm’s partners tested positive for coronavirus, enacting a work-from-home policy for all of its attorneys and staff. A day later, Faegre Drinker [closed its offices worldwide](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/faegre-drinker-worldwide-office-closure-coronavirus/) and enacted a similar policy, if only for a short time, due to a coronavirus scare. All the while, attorneys and staff at other Biglaw firms were left wondering why their firms hadn’t taken any action yet when the technology is available to let them to do their jobs from safe spaces.

As luck would have it, another Biglaw firm has finally decided to allow its lawyers and staff to work from home — and the way they’re doing it is pretty interesting.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Yesterday, Weil Gotshal sent out a memo to let everyone know that the firm’s coronavirus policy had been updated to require mandatory work-from-home sessions on alternating weeks. To accomplish this, the firm will be split into two separate groups, with smaller groups venturing into the office every other week. The firm’s goal here is to minimize the risks of anyone contracting coronavirus through this social distancing program. Weil’s policy will be in effect until further notice.

Here’s an excerpt from the memo, which is available in full on the next page:

Work from Home:  Group A & Group B

Effective, Monday, March 16th, the Firm will assign all attorneys and administrative personnel into two groups:  Group A and Group B.  These groups will alternate working from home on a weekly basis (i.e., Group A will work from home the week of March 16th, Group B will work from home the week of March 23rd, etc.).  This is mandatory and may be adjusted as required outside the United States.  By Friday, March 13th, assigning partners and/or practice group leaders (for attorneys) and managers/supervisors (for administrative personnel) will inform members of their teams of their respective group assignment.

Any administrative staff member who believes that they cannot perform some or all of their regular job functions from home should consult with their immediate supervisor, who will be managing work flow and may be able to provide alternative projects.

Is Weil simply too big to have all of its personnel work from home at the same time? The firm has more than 1,100 lawyers and an untold number of staff. While this isn’t the perfect solution to the coronavirus exposure problem, at least Weil is doing something about it by offering all of its employees this option.

# Biglaw Associate Starts Scholarship To Pay It Forward
## You don't have to wait to start giving back.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onSeptember 9, 2022 at 10:43 AMSeptember 9, 2022 at 10:29 AM
6
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/biglaw-associate-starts-scholarship-to-pay-it-forward/&text=Biglaw%20Associate%20Starts%20Scholarship%20To%20Pay%20It%20Forward)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/biglaw-associate-starts-scholarship-to-pay-it-forward/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/biglaw-associate-starts-scholarship-to-pay-it-forward/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


In this episode, I welcome [Imani Maatuka](https://www.sidley.com/en/people/m/maatuka-imani-n), a Commercial Litigation Associate at Sidley Austin, to talk about the Bridging the Gap Scholarship. Imani recalls what made her decide to follow in the footsteps of her other family members into the legal profession and what the big difference is between what she expected and the reality now that she’s working as a litigation associate. She describes how she picked litigation as the law area to specialize in. Additionally, Imani shares more information about the Bridging the Gap Scholarship: How it started, what their goals and steps to reach these goals are, and how it continues to help other students.

From Pilot and Above The Law  
The Jabot podcast is an offshoot of the Above the Law brand focused on the challenges women, people of color, LGBTQIA, and other diverse populations face in the legal industry. Our name comes from none other than the Notorious Ruth Bader Ginsburg and the jabot (decorative collar) she wore when delivering dissents from the bench. It’s a reminder that even when we aren’t winning, we’re still a powerful force to be reckoned with.

Happy listening!

# The Donald Trump Call Shouldn't Have Been Leaked (If Counsel Were Even Remotely Doing Their Jobs)
## Confidentiality agreements... how do they work?
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJanuary 4, 2021 at 2:14 PMJanuary 4, 2021 at 1:56 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/the-donald-trump-call-shouldnt-have-been-leaked-if-counsel-were-even-remotely-doing-their-jobs/&text=The%20Donald%20Trump%20Call%20Shouldn’t%20Have%20Been%20Leaked%20(If%20Counsel%20Were%20Even%20Remotely%20Doing%20Their%20Jobs))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/the-donald-trump-call-shouldnt-have-been-leaked-if-counsel-were-even-remotely-doing-their-jobs/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/the-donald-trump-call-shouldnt-have-been-leaked-if-counsel-were-even-remotely-doing-their-jobs/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo by Evan Vucci-Pool/Getty Images)

There’s a cacophony of stupid out there calling for Georgia Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger to be arrested, presumably, being the source of the stunning call published by the Washington Post and Atlanta Journal-Constitution where a lame duck president of the United States leaned on state officials to interfere in an election to “find” him the votes he would need to win. We’ve [already dispensed with](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/01/donald-trump-drags-biglaw-firm-into-middle-of-election-interference-effort/) the idea that it was an illegal act of wiretapping (it wasn’t) and that settlement negotiations are privileged (they aren’t), but that doesn’t mean this conversation had to end up in the papers.

And the people responsible for this public firestorm are Donald Trump’s legal counsel.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
It’s a stretch to describe this conversation as a settlement talk — the transcript reads much more like a meet-and-confer to deal with a laundry list of discovery requests — but that’s not really the point. Cleta Mitchell of Foley & Lardner took the President of the United States on a phone call where he could make potentially embarrassing statements about repeatedly debunked conspiracy theories at best and make explicit calls for election fraud at worst and didn’t lay the groundwork by getting a confidentiality agreement?

Just because the conversation wasn’t confidential by operation of law — [or “Man Code”](https://twitter.com/JesseKellyDC/status/1345885052350164992?s=20) — doesn’t mean it couldn’t have been confidential. This is a client who used to have every fling sign an NDA, how do lawyers walk him into a legal and political minefield without securing a confidentiality agreement first? Maybe Michael Cohen really was the brains behind the Trump legal universe all along. A Biglaw lawyer should have thought of this from jump!

Assuming this was a Biglaw effort, of course. For its part, [Foley & Lardner is trying to distance itself from Mitchell](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2021/01/04/lincoln-project-takes-on-foley-lardner-over-partners-role-in-trumps-call-to-georgia/), saying “[a]ny involvement [by Cleta Mitchell] in this matter is solely in his or her capacity as a private citizen.”



###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Not sure that firms get to disavow partners running side gigs that easily. From ethical canons to malpractice insurance, there’s a whole litany of obligations that firms must shoulder based on the actions of any of their attorneys. It’s why one of the first things a firm tells first-year associates is that they can’t go around offering legal advice to their friends and family because they’re in a firm now. And it’s hard to sell [the contents of this transcript](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-raffensperger-call-transcript-georgia-vote/2021/01/03/2768e0cc-4ddd-11eb-83e3-322644d82356_story.html) as anything but a member of their firm actively providing legal advice. For example:

Germany: We chose Cobb County because that was the only county where there’s been any evidence submitted that the signature verification was not properly done.

Trump: No, but I told you. We’re not, we’re not saying that.

Mitchell: We did say that.

That certainly sounds like someone preparing the filings.

But even if Mitchell wasn’t backed by the army of cautious senior associates who should have pointed out the need for some kind of confidentiality agreement, it should be lawyering 101.

So if Trump and his allies want to blame anyone for this tape getting out and hurting the president, they may want to blame their own counsel.

# Layoffs LITERALLY Decimate Am Law 100 Firm
## Ten percent of attorneys and staff on chopping block.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onFebruary 13, 2024 at 4:29 PM
13
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/02/layoffs-literally-decimate-am-law-100-firm/&text=Layoffs%20LITERALLY%20Decimate%20Am%20Law%20100%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/02/layoffs-literally-decimate-am-law-100-firm/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/02/layoffs-literally-decimate-am-law-100-firm/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
People have misused the word “decimate” for so long it’s entirely acceptable to use to describe any substantially destructive event. But, technically, the term describes a coldly applied 10 percent reduction. To be more specific, a Roman military punishment where a unit would draw lots and one-tenth of the soldiers would be executed to teach the whole unit a lesson for being involved in the failure of their officers.

Which sort of makes decimation the first layoff.

Fenwick & West — number 66 in the last Am Law rankings — issued its own little [Order 66](https://starwars.fandom.com/wiki/Order_66) and started offing associates and staff today. And [according to Bloomberg](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/fenwick-west-laying-off-nearly-10-of-attorneys-staff), we’re looking at about 10 percent:

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
After an “assessment of current and anticipated future demand,” the firm made the decision to reduce its workforce, firm chair Richard Dickson said in an email viewed by Bloomberg Law sent Tuesday afternoon. The reductions will affect “just under” 10% of the firm’s professionals, he said.

We believe in rounding and “just under” means it’s 10 percent. The firm knows these cuts round up too, or it would’ve written “just over 9 percent” because it just sounds way less horrible when it’s in single-digits.

Law firms are, by and large, reporting decent profits and slow but steady improvements in demand. Unfortunately, there are outliers and for the past couple years, those outliers tend to have deep ties to the tech sector. Fenwick fits smack in the middle of that cohort.

Which, for anyone keeping score, was also a Roman military unit.

# Morning Docket: 10.02.18
## * Police questioned Brett Kavanaugh over a bar fight he and Chris Dudley apparently got into -- wait, Chris Dudley? This whole "Brett + Alcohol = Violence" equation is becoming a pattern. And a pattern he lies about under oath. [[NY Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/01/us/politics/kavanaugh-bar-fight.html)] * Department of Justice sues California over its net neutrality law. So much for states' rights. [[Courthouse News Service](https://www.courthousenews.com/feds-sue-to-stop-california-bid-for-net-neutrality/)] * Law firms are merging at a record pace. This should probably worry people more. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/2018/10/01/law-firm-mergers-continue-at-record-pace-through-third-quarter/)] * This reads more like an exam question than real life. Is it a trademark violation to spell fiance as Feyoncé when selling engagement gifts? What if we add that they also sold stuff that references "Single Ladies"? [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/1088036/beyonc-can-t-shut-down-feyonc-merchandise)] * Sidley Austin earns less than the midlevel exception. Or about what Chris Dudley was worth. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/10/01/labor-department-filing-reveals-big-sidley-payday-in-basketball-dispute/)] * The Supreme Court is open for business. Will they further limit access to justice this Term? Probably, yeah. [[National Law Journal](https://www.law.com/nationallawjournal/2018/10/01/will-the-supreme-court-further-limit-access-to-justice/)] * "SEC Suit Over Elon Musk's Tweets Sets an Example for Execs Online." Indeed: Don't Date Grimes. [[Corporate Counsel](https://www.law.com/corpcounsel/2018/10/01/sec-suit-over-elon-musks-tweets-sets-an-example-for-execs-online/)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onOctober 2, 2018 at 8:25 AMOctober 2, 2018 at 7:17 AM
12
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/morning-docket-10-02-18/&text=Morning%20Docket:%2010.02.18)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/morning-docket-10-02-18/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/10/morning-docket-10-02-18/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

* Law firms are merging at a record pace. This should probably worry people more. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/2018/10/01/law-firm-mergers-continue-at-record-pace-through-third-quarter/)]

# NY To $180K: The First Major Match
## What you've been waiting for: a match of the Cravath scale from a large New York law firm.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onJune 7, 2016 at 10:52 AMJune 8, 2016 at 1:34 PM
42
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/ny-to-180k-the-first-major-match/&text=NY%20To%20$180K:%20The%20First%20Major%20Match)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/ny-to-180k-the-first-major-match/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/ny-to-180k-the-first-major-match/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Sure, it was lovely when [Hueston Hennigan matched the new Cravath salary scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/another-firm-bumps-associate-salaries-to-match-180k-scale/) Monday night, but we know what you’ve all been waiting for. Elite litigation boutiques in California are nice and all, but what are the major players in New York going to do on associate base salaries?

We now bring you the first major match. [Milbank Tweed](https://abovethelaw.com/law-firms/milbank-tweed-hadley-mccloy/) — a definite Biglaw firm, [Am Law 100 and NLJ 350](http://www.americanlawyer.com/law-firm-profiles-result?firmname=Milbank+Tweed+Hadley+%26+McCloy&slreturn=20160507104204), with more than 600 lawyers and $700 million in annual revenue — has matched the [Cravath salary scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/breaking-ny-to-180k-cravath-raises-associate-base-salaries/?rf=1).

This doesn’t come as much of a surprise. You’ll recall that in the last bonus season, Milbank matched Cravath [within an hour](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/12/associate-bonus-watch-the-first-cravath-match-wow-that-was-fast/). This time, on salary news, Milbank waited until the next day. What took them so long? 😉

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Our Milbank sources are pleased:

- “Milbank definitely tries it’s best to appreciate associates, and while it’s not a comp leader it has always been committed to paying the top of the market. It’s also really nice that the firm ensures we don’t have to wait around too long to hear.”
- “Welcome news. I’m happy to be working at a firm that recognizes how important it is to be on par with its peers to retain the best talent.”
Congrats, Milbank associates, on the enhanced salaries!

UPDATE (11:10 a.m.): An important point raised by a reader: “Which offices does the Milbank raise cover? That would be big news if we now have the raise spreading to non-NYC offices.”

###Sponsored

From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
It seems to cover all of Milbank’s U.S. offices — specifically, Los Angeles and Washington as well as New York. The memo does not contain “NYC only” language, and the email transmitting the memo got sent to #LA Associates and #DC Associates as well as #NY Associates. So this bodes well for the Cravath pay raise spreading beyond New York. (Recall that Cravath itself has only New York and London offices.)

UPDATE (11:20 a.m.) For anyone who’s interested, I’ll be on CNBC’s [Power Lunch](http://www.cnbc.com/power-lunch-cnbc/) at around 2:15 p.m. today to talk about the Biglaw pay raise news. Please tune in if so inclined!

UPDATE (3:37 p.m.) In case you’re wondering, yes, incoming Milbank associates (class of 2016) will be getting the new $180,000 salary. They recently received this information from recruiting: “The Executive Committee announced an increase to our associate salary scale earlier today; the memo is attached. The annual salary for the Class of 2016 will be $180,000.”

UPDATE (6/8/2016, 1:37 p.m.) Consistent with [Paul Weiss and several other firms](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/ny-to-180k-the-raises-spread-to-summer-associates/), Milbank will be paying its summer associates at the new going rate for first-year associates:

# Which Biglaw Firms Will Cover Travel Expenses For Employees Who Can No Longer Access Abortion Care?
## Some firms are willing to devote resources to make sure their employees have access to abortion.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJune 27, 2022 at 12:16 PMNovember 21, 2022 at 11:32 AM
4
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/which-biglaw-firms-will-cover-travel-expenses-for-employees-who-can-no-longer-access-abortion-care/&text=Which%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Will%20Cover%20Travel%20Expenses%20For%20Employees%20Who%20Can%20No%20Longer%20Access%20Abortion%20Care?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/which-biglaw-firms-will-cover-travel-expenses-for-employees-who-can-no-longer-access-abortion-care/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/which-biglaw-firms-will-cover-travel-expenses-for-employees-who-can-no-longer-access-abortion-care/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo by Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images)

Of the most elite Biglaw firms — the Am Law 100 — 76 have offices in [states that have banned or severely limited access to abortion rights](https://www.guttmacher.org/article/2021/10/26-states-are-certain-or-likely-ban-abortion-without-roe-heres-which-ones-and-why) in the wake of [the Dobbs decision.](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/the-end-of-roe-is-here/) Biglaw’s rapid expansion into Texas sure looms large. For those thousands who work at those firms (and folks who work at other firms that key their benefits off of what the top of Biglaw does), the VERY important question is — what are they going to do about it?

Sure, things like pro bono opportunities and devoting the firm’s mighty resources to the fight for abortion rights is incredibly important — vital even. But let’s take it out of the esoteric and talk about the actual folks working at those firms who are finding out right now that they’re pregnant. What will those firms do for employees who suddenly find themselves cut off from abortion, and potentially a wide range of fertility treatments?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
All sorts of [major companies are making news](https://www.cnn.com/2022/06/24/tech/companies-abortion-reaction/index.html) for stepping up for their employees and covering travel expenses for those who wish to access abortion care. Will Biglaw do the same?

Above the Law reached out to Am Law 100 firms that operate offices in locations (all 76 of them) where abortion has already been banned/restricted to find out what their plan is — they did have eight weeks ([from the leak of the draft decision](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/unprecedented-scotus-leak-shows-just-how-little-respect-the-court-has-for-you-know-precedent/)) to figure it out. We’ll be updating the chart as we learn more details. Not only is it vital for folks currently working at the firm, but as law students begin the recruitment process in a few months, they can use this info to find out what kind of firm they’re considering working for.

And please, if you know information drop us a line — text (646-820-8477) or [email](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Travel%20Costs) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Travel Costs”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file. All sources are kept strictly confidential.

And if your firm fails to come through, maybe Dick’s Sporting Goods’ legal department is hiring.
