# Biglaw Firms Gets In On The Associate Raise Game -- PLUS -- Bonus News
## Associate raises are still happening!
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 20, 2018 at 10:43 AMDecember 20, 2018 at 9:40 AM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/biglaw-firms-gets-in-on-the-associate-raise-game-plus-bonus-news/&text=Biglaw%20Firms%20Gets%20In%20On%20The%20Associate%20Raise%20Game%20—%20PLUS%20—%20Bonus%20News)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/biglaw-firms-gets-in-on-the-associate-raise-game-plus-bonus-news/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/biglaw-firms-gets-in-on-the-associate-raise-game-plus-bonus-news/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Though the powers that be at McKool Smith haven’t come forward with an announcement of lockstep associate raises or bonuses, that doesn’t mean the attorneys there are stuck in the old salary scale forever. According to tipsters at the firm, the individual notifications went out at the firm and most people seem very pleased.

Based on our information, the annual end-of-year bonuses are in line (at least on average) with the [bonus scale set by Cravath](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/breaking-cravath-announces-annual-bonuses/) last month. But the really exciting news is that the firm is moving to the new [$190K salary scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/new-york-to-190k-no-cravath-didnt-make-the-first-move/) that became all the rage during this summer’s salary wars. And those raises will be retroactive to July 1, meaning associates will get a lump sum payment — styled as a special bonus — that makes up the difference between their old salaries and [the new scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/cravath-hath-spoken-and-beats-milbank-for-senior-associates/).

That’s some great holiday news indeed!

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)

### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)

# Twitter’s ‘Cost Cutting By Not Paying Bills’ Now Going To Increase Legal Fees
## How to destroy a company.
By [Techdirt](https://abovethelaw.com/author/techdirt/)  
onJanuary 6, 2023 at 10:03 AMJanuary 6, 2023 at 9:12 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/twitters-cost-cutting-by-not-paying-bills-now-going-to-increase-legal-fees/&text=Twitter’s%20‘Cost%20Cutting%20By%20Not%20Paying%20Bills’%20Now%20Going%20To%20Increase%20Legal%20Fees)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/twitters-cost-cutting-by-not-paying-bills-now-going-to-increase-legal-fees/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/01/twitters-cost-cutting-by-not-paying-bills-now-going-to-increase-legal-fees/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s no secret that Elon Musk is desperately trying to cut costs at Twitter, the company he overpaid for and saddled with approximately an extra billion dollars a year in interest payments by leveraging the buyout. He’s cut staff somewhere around 75% and we still keep hearing rumors of further cuts. He’s [turning off data centers](https://www.techdirt.com/2022/12/29/it-took-just-four-days-from-elon-gleefully-admitting-hed-unplugged-a-server-rack-for-twitter-to-have-a-major-outage/) as well. Though, as part of all this, he’s also [driven away a huge percentage](https://www.techdirt.com/2022/12/22/elon-appears-to-admit-that-hes-driven-away-40-of-twitters-advertisers/) of Twitter’s revenue, as well as any sort of momentum towards growth.

A month ago, the NY Times noted that one of Musk’s cost savings techniques [appeared to be to just stop paying Twitter’s bills](https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/13/technology/elon-musk-twitter-shakeup.html?smid=tw-nytimes&smtyp=cur).

To cut costs, Twitter has not paid rent for its San Francisco headquarters or any of its global offices for weeks, three people close to the company said. Twitter has also refused to pay a $197,725 bill for private charter flights made the week of Mr. Musk’s takeover, according to a copy of a lawsuit filed in New Hampshire District Court and obtained by The New York Times.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
There are also a bunch of other stories about not paying law firms and a variety of other vendors as well. Last week there were [more details on the “data center closure” order](https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/29/technology/twitter-elon-musk.html) from Musk which, as we had heard rumored, was done haphazardly with little advance planning or care.

Elon Musk’s orders were clear: Close the data center.

Early on Christmas Eve, members of the billionaire’s staff flew to Sacramento — the site of one of Twitter’s three main computing storage facilities — to disconnect servers that had kept the social network running smoothly. Some employees were worried that losing those servers could cause problems, but saving money was the priority, according to two people who were familiar with the move but not authorized to talk about it.

Of course, for most people, not paying your bills is not seen as a “cost cutting” move, it’s called ruining your credit and risking all sorts of downstream problems. I guess when you’re filthy stinking rich (even if you’ve [lost more money than anyone ever](https://news.yahoo.com/tesla-ceo-elon-musk-first-145155563.html) in history), it’s called “renegotiating.”

But I do wonder if this kind of “cost cutting” may come with a lot more additional costs than someone like Musk has realized. We’ve already talked about the very real threats [from the FTC](https://www.techdirt.com/2022/12/26/elon-musk-claims-hes-not-worried-about-the-ftc-he-should-be/) and [the EU](https://www.techdirt.com/2022/11/16/if-you-thought-the-ftc-was-going-to-fuck-over-elon-just-wait-until-he-learns-about-the-eu/) cracking down on Twitter for violating various laws and agreements. Those can come with massive fines.

But also, all this “cost cutting by not paying the bills” seems to be turning into lawsuits. Twitter is [closing down its offices in Seattle entirely](https://www.seattletimes.com/business/facing-eviction-twitter-closes-seattle-office-reports-say/), as it’s facing eviction for not paying rent. The few remaining employees were apparently told to work from home, which is at least mildly amusing coming less than two months after Musk [gave everyone an ultimatum](https://abc7news.com/elon-musk-twitter-return-to-office-employees-blue/12444456/) to return to the office immediately.

But now there’s at least one landlord who is suing. Columbia REIT, which manages 650 California in San Francisco, [is suing the company for unpaid rent](https://s3.documentcloud.org/documents/23561523/twitter-rent.pdf). This is not Twitter’s headquarters (where it’s also been reported the company is not paying rent) at 1355 Market Street. Rather this was some office space that Twitter took over when [it purchased](https://www.adweek.com/programmatic/twitter-buys-mobile-dsp-crossinstall-as-it-prioritizes-performance-ads/) mobile advertising tech firm CrossInstall in 2020. That deal came with the lease on CrossInstall’s offices at 650 California St. Rather than actually use the space, Twitter apparently has been subletting it out to Dentsu, but Twitter is still responsible for the rent.

From the documents, it appears that Dentsu pays Twitter slightly less than what Twitter has to pay the REIT for the space. So, based on this, it is possible that not only is Twitter not paying the rent, which may screw over Dentsu, but it may be taking the money from Dentsu in the meantime.

Still, I imagine these types of lawsuits are going to start to add up, and the legal bills associated with them may start to be even more costly than, you know, paying for the basic things Twitter promised to pay for. Musk may think he can get away with that by also not paying the lawyers, but there are few professions I know of that get more pissed off about being stiffed on bills than lawyers.

He’s Elon Musk, so maybe he’ll get out of all of this as well, but it still strikes me that there was always a less costly way to do this: don’t immediately fire everyone, spend some time figuring out where you can cut costs, put in place some real effort to retain existing revenue, and then work on ways to renegotiate other contracts while still paying your bills.

# Want To Sue ChatGPT? Too Bad!
## Which law firm is willing to test this AI chatbot's theory?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onFebruary 14, 2023 at 3:43 PMFebruary 15, 2023 at 8:42 AM
20
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/want-to-sue-chatgpt-too-bad/&text=Want%20To%20Sue%20ChatGPT?%20Too%20Bad!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/want-to-sue-chatgpt-too-bad/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/02/want-to-sue-chatgpt-too-bad/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As an AI language model, I cannot be sued.

— ChatGPT, in response to a question asked by a [Law.com International](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/02/13/hello-chatgpt-which-is-the-best-law-firm-in-the-world-405-117321/) reporter, on which elite Biglaw firm it would choose if it were being sued.

# Oops! Biglaw Partner Sent Private Strategy Presentation To Adversary In 'CC' Snafu
## It's okay, I'm sure it wasn't potentially damaging...
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onAugust 13, 2021 at 12:12 PMAugust 13, 2021 at 11:36 AM
12
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/oops-biglaw-partner-sent-private-strategy-presentation-to-adversary-in-cc-snafu/&text=Oops!%20Biglaw%20Partner%20Sent%20Private%20Strategy%20Presentation%20To%20Adversary%20In%20‘CC’%20Snafu)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/oops-biglaw-partner-sent-private-strategy-presentation-to-adversary-in-cc-snafu/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/oops-biglaw-partner-sent-private-strategy-presentation-to-adversary-in-cc-snafu/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As an attorney, I made the “inadvertent email” mistake just once. Thankfully, it was an innocuous note about an associate lunch to co-defendant’s counsel because they had the same first name and Outlook trades expediency for common sense if you don’t turn off its “suggested recipients” feature with extreme prejudice.

It’s unclear if it was a “suggested recipients” problem or a “reply all” issue, but Proskauer partner Michael Lebowich, representing the New York Times, made a similar mistake recently. Except instead of accidentally inviting another firm partner to lunch, [he sent his adversaries a private strategy presentation](https://www.thedailybeast.com/ny-times-lawyers-accidentally-send-private-strategy-memo-to-staff-union). All the news that’s fit to print doesn’t stop for management’s confidentiality concerns!

Tech workers for the Times are unionizing and rather than voluntarily recognize the union like a reasonable entity, the newspaper demanded a vote to buy management time to undermine the effort before election day.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Right now, the paper is fighting over the scope of the possible union. As the Daily Beast reports:

In one slide, titled “Operating Principles,” the lawyers discussed management’s potential goals, including ensuring supervisors are not involved in the union, seeking the “smallest bargaining unit that is justifiable,” or seeking “the bargaining unit where we are most likely to win an election” that would effectively defeat the unionization effort.

The larger potential union might actually allow the paper to “win” the election by expanding the pool of voters and increasing the chance that enough senior workers might sell out junior workers by rejecting the union. On the other hand, a smaller union would almost certainly have the votes to form, but would cabin the impact on management. Proskauer advises the latter strategy.

This isn’t hugely surprising. The Daily Beast spoke with an organizing member of the union who found it valuable that counsel advised the paper to more or less concede the union as inevitable and work to limit its size as opposed to risking a larger unit in a fight to defeat the effort wholesale. Though, honestly, the workers probably sussed this out as a likely strategy before getting this slide deck. It’s not like union busting is a new industry — the tactics are well-established.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…

### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.

From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
But what might actually muck up Proskauer’s client from this presentation is a slide purporting to show union support among the workers. The graph breaks down workers into different departments and shows the level of backing for “leans yes, leans no, on the fence, and unknown.” This suggests management is polling employees on their thoughts about the union which happens to be [totally illegal](https://www.nlrb.gov/about-nlrb/rights-we-protect/the-law/interfering-with-employee-rights-section-7-8a1). The union has filed complaints with the NLRB.

Which all goes to show how important it is not to get careless with your carbon copies, lawyers! Every email is a time bomb for your clients — unless you’re emailing lunch plans — so don’t skimp on the protections. To be extra careful, you can even create a rule that holds all sent messages for 30 seconds (or more) to give the sender enough time to have an “OH CRAP” moment before the message actually hits the ether. There are a ton of bells and whistles in the software that lawyers can use to stay safe.

And if Proskauer has trouble figuring out how to implement any of these tech fixes, I’m sure there’s a tech staffer at the Times more than willing to demonstrate how valuable they are.

# This Is How Biglaw Associates Can Avoid Getting Laid Off
## It's time to do even more work -- if there's any available, that is.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onSeptember 12, 2022 at 5:47 PMSeptember 12, 2022 at 4:07 PM
26
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/this-is-how-biglaw-associates-can-avoid-getting-laid-off/&text=This%20Is%20How%20Biglaw%20Associates%20Can%20Avoid%20Getting%20Laid%20Off)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/this-is-how-biglaw-associates-can-avoid-getting-laid-off/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/09/this-is-how-biglaw-associates-can-avoid-getting-laid-off/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
If associates are smart, they will take what work they can and make themselves busy. If things do get worse, firms will look at overall productivity. You never want the associate who always has time, because there’s a reason for it. I think those will be the most vulnerable people.

— [Jeff Lowe](https://www.mlaglobal.com/en/people/jeffrey-lowe), global managing partner of legal recruiter Major, Lindsey & Africa, offering his thoughts to [Law.com](https://www.law.com/2022/09/12/cuts-or-normalization-firms-scale-back-recruiting-as-recession-fears-loom/) on how Biglaw associates can keep busy to avoid possible layoffs should the economy grow worse.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).


##Enter your email address to sign up for ATL's Layoff Alerts.

# Morning Docket: 09.05.17
## * As we continue to reel from Judge Posner's retirement, here are some of his best quips. Unfortunately lists like these will always miss something. Like [my personal favorite](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/09/judge-posner-rips-poor-winston-strawn-lawyer/): “Yeah, but, you know, the problem with the balancing test is there’s nothing on your side of the balance!” [[National Law Journal](http://www.nationallawjournal.com/id=1202797211650/)] * The high price of becoming a partner. [[American Lawyer](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202797118310/The-Cost-of-Making-Partner-and-How-Senior-Associates-Should-Prepare/)] * Top Kasowitz Benson partner jumps ship... could this be more fallout from the ill-fated attempt to defend Trump? [[New York Law Journal](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202797184852/Leading-Partner-at-Kasowitz-Benson-to-Leave-for-Kirkland-amp-Ellis/)] * The government's been in a slump at the Supreme Court. [[Empirical SCOTUS](https://empiricalscotus.com/2017/09/03/governments-recent-cases/)] * A deep dive into the Chadbourne discrimination suit. [[Bloomberg Businessweek](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2017-09-05/how-america-s-top-law-firms-get-away-with-paying-women-less)] * If you've not followed the phenomenon of running [payday lending from tribal lands](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/09/the-legal-trick-payday-lenders-are-using-to-skirt-the-law/), here's an in depth look at a $2B lawsuit over the practice. [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/960162/-2b-trial-puts-tribal-payday-lending-in-spotlight-/)] * Some predictions about the upcoming law school application cycle. Here's another one... a bunch of people will end up in debt for no good reason. [[US News](https://www.usnews.com/education/blogs/law-admissions-lowdown/articles/2017-09-04/check-out-predictions-about-2017-2018-law-school-application-trends)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onSeptember 5, 2017 at 7:59 AM

# Amid Fallout From Antisemitic Rants, George Floyd Conspiracy Theories, And More, Kanye West Turns To Familiar Biglaw Face For Legal Help
## Biglaw isn't just for corporate issues.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onOctober 24, 2022 at 11:46 AMOctober 26, 2022 at 10:18 AM
12
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/amid-fallout-from-antisemitic-rants-george-floyd-conspiracy-theories-and-more-kanye-west-turns-to-familiar-biglaw-face-for-legal-help/&text=Amid%20Fallout%20From%20Antisemitic%20Rants,%20George%20Floyd%20Conspiracy%20Theories,%20And%20More,%20Kanye%20West%20Turns%20To%20Familiar%20Biglaw%20Face%20For%20Legal%20Help)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/amid-fallout-from-antisemitic-rants-george-floyd-conspiracy-theories-and-more-kanye-west-turns-to-familiar-biglaw-face-for-legal-help/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/amid-fallout-from-antisemitic-rants-george-floyd-conspiracy-theories-and-more-kanye-west-turns-to-familiar-biglaw-face-for-legal-help/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo by Ronald Martinez/Getty Images)

CHECK OUT THE UPDATE: [Brown Rudnick is backing away from Ye.](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/biglaw-firm-passes-on-representing-kanye-west-after-rapper-refuses-to-back-away-from-antisemitic-remarks/)

Kanye West’s never been one to steer away from controversy, but lately it’s gotten even worse. He launched antisemitic attacks on social media that got him booted from Twitter, and teed up [buying Parler](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/10/yes-buyout-of-parler-looks-very-much-like-a-failed-company-taking-advantage-of-troubled-rich-guy/). [He spread](https://www.npr.org/2022/10/19/1129747423/kanye-west-george-floyd-lawsuit) vicious, unfounded rumors that it wasn’t former police officer Derek Chauvin that caused George Floyd’s death but rather fentanyl — and as a result is facing a $250 million lawsuit. He wore a [“White Lives Matter” shirt](https://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/pictures/kanye-wests-white-lives-matter-drama-everything-to-know/) to his Yeezy fashion show. He’s been [dropped](https://jezebel.com/balenciaga-has-officially-dumped-kanye-west-1849687883) by Balenciaga and his Adidas contract is “[under review.”](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/kanye-west-ye-adidas-antisemitic-comments-adl-anti-defamation-league/)

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Ye’s troubles have clearly branched out beyond the public relations sphere and into legal woes. As such, [TMZ is reporting](https://www.tmz.com/2022/10/21/kanye-west-hire-johnny-depp-attorney-camille-vasquez-amber-heard-yeezy-business/) Ye hired a Biglaw firm to represent his “business interests.” He’ll be working with Brown Rudnick and specifically partner [Camille Vasquez](https://brownrudnick.com/people/camille-m-vasquez/). Vasquez’s [rising legal star](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/fan-favorite-lawyer-in-johnny-depp-case-gets-promoted-to-partner-at-her-biglaw-firm/) recently translated to pop culture relevance during her[ successful representation](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/fan-favorite-lawyer-in-johnny-depp-case-speaks-out-after-verdict/) of Johnny Depp in his defamation case against Amber Heard.

While Vasquez will potentially be involved in a variety of mounting Ye legal troubles, one court battle she’s staying out of is his custody case. The rapper [recently hired](https://www.tmz.com/2022/09/28/kanye-west-kim-kardashian-melinda-gates-divorce-lawyer/) Robert Cohen — who represented Melinda Gates in her divorce from Bill Gates — and Nicholas Salick in his ongoing dispute with ex-wife Kim Kardashian. This is Ye’s sixth set of attorneys in his family law case.

We’ll see if Vasquez has more lasting power as Ye’s attorney.

# The Pink Ghetto: Reports Of Biglaw Sexual Assault In The Days Following Donald Trump's Election
## This is absolutely horrifying.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 11, 2016 at 12:04 PMNovember 13, 2016 at 7:28 PM
263
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/the-pink-ghetto-biglaw-sexual-assault-in-the-days-following-donald-trumps-election/&text=The%20Pink%20Ghetto:%20Reports%20Of%20Biglaw%20Sexual%20Assault%20In%20The%20Days%20Following%20Donald%20Trump’s%20Election)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/the-pink-ghetto-biglaw-sexual-assault-in-the-days-following-donald-trumps-election/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/11/the-pink-ghetto-biglaw-sexual-assault-in-the-days-following-donald-trumps-election/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

President-elect Donald Trump (Photo by Win McNamee/Getty)

Welcome back to [The Pink Ghetto](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/the-pink-ghetto/), a series where we take a look at some of the most appalling stories from one of the most sexist industries in the world: the legal profession. While we’ve heard of countless instances of discrimination and sexual harassment that have occurred since the results of the election were announced, this one is beyond the pale. Today, we’ll take a look at the ways in which sexual harassment and assault at law firms have been amplified in the days since the election of Donald Trump. This is a real email that we’ve received from a real reader.

When you see things like this happening, say something. Together, we can inspire the change necessary to stop this disturbing behavior from being so prevalent in the law.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
I am a paralegal in an Am Law 200 firm in the south. I am of Hispanic descent. My colleagues and I regularly face unwanted sexual remarks made by associates and sometimes partners, but they’re usually said in hushed tones, either behind our backs, or sometimes as they walk away from our desks. Despite their attempts to remain quiet, we’ve always caught bits and pieces of the foul things they’ve said about us. So-and-so is a piece of ass. You’d like so-and-so as your side piece. You bet so-and-so sucks a mean dick. You want to get so-and-so in your office and fuck her good. So-and-so won’t be able to say no if she wants to keep her job.

Thankfully, these comments were never made directly to our faces. We thought they knew better.

In the days since Trump has been elected, the situation has become almost unbearable. These vile, highly sexual comments that were once whispered are now spoken in full voice. Associates had always allowed their hands to brush against us, if briefly, but never like this. Some of us, myself included, have been touched inappropriately.

Yesterday, an associate took his opportunity as I bent over to retrieve a binder, his hand cupping my rear, his fingers dipping lower in an attempt to touch my most intimate areas. Sensing one of my colleagues approaching, he pulled away, grunting, “Next time, I’ll grab you by the pussy, beaner.”

Are we to be preyed upon like this for the next four years? Have these men forgotten that they’re lawyers? What has our country become?

This story is absolutely horrifying. If you work at a law firm where things like this happen, please report those who are involved to HR, immediately. Do not wait for this situation to escalate any further than it already has. Please take action, NOW.

Do you have a law school or law firm story you’d like to see appear in The Pink Ghetto? Please [email me](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com?subject=The%20Pink%20Ghetto) with “The Pink Ghetto” in the subject line (or find me on Twitter: [@StaciZaretsky](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky)). You will be kept anonymous. Submissions are always welcome.

# The Financials From A Single Biglaw Firm Are Dragging Down The Entire Industry
## Any comparison to the dark days of 2008-09 can be a scary one for associates.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onSeptember 27, 2016 at 2:53 PM
8
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/the-financials-from-a-single-biglaw-firm-are-dragging-down-the-entire-industry/&text=The%20Financials%20From%20A%20Single%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Are%20Dragging%20Down%20The%20Entire%20Industry)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/the-financials-from-a-single-biglaw-firm-are-dragging-down-the-entire-industry/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/the-financials-from-a-single-biglaw-firm-are-dragging-down-the-entire-industry/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
As ATL noted yesterday for the first time since the Great Recession, the revenue per lawyer, or RPL, as tracked by [American Lawyer](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202768367950/For-the-Worlds-TopGrossing-Firms-Slow-and-Steady-Growth?mcode=0&curindex=0&curpage=ALL)‘s Global 100 has taken a dip. And that dip is caused by a single law firm:

What could have caused this decline in revenue per lawyer? We’ll refer to this as the Dentons dip. As noted by Am Law, thanks to the firm’s mega-merger with Dacheng — a firm 4,000 lawyers strong — RPL for the entire Global 100 sank like a stone. But for the Dentons Dacheng merger, the Global 100’s RPL would have increased by 0.2 percent, to $841,346. However, while 23 firms saw an increase in RPL of over 5 percent, more than a third experienced declines in 2015 — the most since the Great Recession. This could be a trend worth watching over the course of this year.

And it’s becoming clear that this market shift is far from typical, as Big Law Business [reports](https://bol.bna.com/one-mega-firm-dragged-legal-industry-ranking-report/):

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Bruce MacEwen, a law firm consultant who has been outspoken about The American Lawyer financial rankings, said that he’s never seen an entire metric skewed by a single law firm.

“That is new to me,” he said. “It had to happen, sooner or later, because these firms are getting so big.”

But as MacEwen does note, Dentons’ unique structure, that of a verein — different law firms that work under the same brand — also plays into their surprisingly low revenue per lawyer.

Now Dentons has responded to American Lawyer’s report. Perhaps unsurprisingly the firm takes the position that this metric doesn’t reflect the quality of the firm or the work they do:

As you know, Dentons has a longstanding policy of not commenting on the accuracy of estimates of Dentons’ global financial performance made by the media. However, this story reinforces a point that we have made consistently: focusing on global averages of financial figures such as RPL or PEP reveals virtually nothing regarding the legal profession, the quality of a firm or its success. The wide variance in economic standards across the multiple regions served by a global law firm makes such global averages meaningless. The American Lawyer’s observation that one large firm can change the average by itself demonstrates our basic point — averages often disguise meaningful information, not provide it. Dentons continues to measure its success through the integration, growth and innovation initiatives that enhance our service offerings to clients, not the pursuit of irrelevant metrics.

# Morning Docket: 11.13.17
## * Per recently filed FEC paperwork, the Republican Party's campaign arm has severed financial ties with would-be Alabama senator Roy Moore thanks to his allegedly pervy predilections. If there's no grass on the field, the GOP won't play ball, but this man will probably still be elected. [[The Daily Beast](https://www.thedailybeast.com/senate-gop-campaign-arm-severs-financial-ties-to-roy-moore)] * Starting today, members of the public will be able to access briefs and relevant case documents from the Supreme Court's website for the first time in history. This will be pretty cool for a day or two, and then people will go back SCOTUSblog, to the OG of high court documentation. [[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/courts_law/the-supreme-courts-next-cautious-careful-move-into-the-digital-age/2017/11/12/c724eef6-c7cd-11e7-b0cf-7689a9f2d84e_story.html?utm_term=.fe8c148f374b)] * After seeing a five-year nose-dive, the number of LSAT-takers has ticked upwards ever so slightly over the course of the past two years. Law schools are probably thrilled given the dearth of quality applicants, but this is likely little comfort for the LSAC given the unexpected rise of the GRE. [[Law.com](http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/11/10/lsat-takers-trending-up-following-five-year-plunge-why/?LikelyCookieIssue=true)] * Late last week, a judge ruled favorably for Kerrie Campbell in a discovery dispute in her gender bias case against the now-defunct Chadbourne & Parke. Campbell will be able to review the personal email accounts of the firm's former leaders for any documents relevant to the case. [[American Lawyer](http://www.law.com/americanlawyer/sites/americanlawyer/2017/11/09/110917chadbourne_emails/)] * A 12-year-old girl who suffers from debilitating seizures and was forced to move from Texas to Colorado for treatment is suing Attorney General Jeff Sessions in an effort to legalize medical marijuana nationwide. The government has already lost its first motion to dismiss her case. [[The Hill](http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/359929-12-year-old-suing-sessions-over-marijuana-policy)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onNovember 13, 2017 at 8:46 AMNovember 12, 2017 at 8:56 PM
35

* Starting today, members of the public will be able to access briefs and relevant case documents from the Supreme Court’s website for the first time in history. This will be pretty cool for a day or two, and then people will go back SCOTUSblog, to the OG of high court documentation. From Pilot and Above The Law  

* After seeing a five-year nose-dive, the number of LSAT-takers has ticked upwards ever so slightly over the course of the past two years. Law schools are probably thrilled given the dearth of quality applicants, but this is likely little comfort for the LSAC given the unexpected rise of the GRE. [[Law.com](http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/11/10/lsat-takers-trending-up-following-five-year-plunge-why/?LikelyCookieIssue=true)]

* Late last week, a judge ruled favorably for Kerrie Campbell in a discovery dispute in her gender bias case against the now-defunct Chadbourne & Parke. Campbell will be able to review the personal email accounts of the firm’s former leaders for any documents relevant to the case. [[American Lawyer](http://www.law.com/americanlawyer/sites/americanlawyer/2017/11/09/110917chadbourne_emails/)]

* A 12-year-old girl who suffers from debilitating seizures and was forced to move from Texas to Colorado for treatment is suing Attorney General Jeff Sessions in an effort to legalize medical marijuana nationwide. The government has already lost its first motion to dismiss her case. [[The Hill](http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/359929-12-year-old-suing-sessions-over-marijuana-policy)]
